issues.description: The solution repository changes the structure of PersonService by adding a new constructor parameter and attribute (PersonRepository) that do not exist in the template. The problem statement explicitly warns students "Do not change the attributes of PersonService". The solution's PersonService now requires a PersonRepository bean via constructor injection, but the solution only provides an interface (PersonRepository) without any implementation or Spring bean definition. This mismatch (1) contradicts the instruction in the problem statement, (2) differs from the template's no-arg PersonService, and (3) creates a runtime/configuration barrier because Spring will fail to inject a PersonRepository bean unless an implementation/bean is provided. Students comparing the template and the solution (or trying to run the solution) may be confused or blocked by this structural change.
issues.suggested_fix:
Make the solution consistent with the template and the problem statement. Either:
1) Remove the PersonRepository dependency from PersonService in the solution (restore the no-arg constructor and do not add new attributes), or
2) If a repository is required, provide a concrete Spring bean implementation (e.g., annotate an implementation with @Repository or make the interface extend a Spring Data repository like JpaRepository and configure persistence) so that Spring can inject it. Also update the template/problem statement consistently if the design is intended to include a repository. Ensure the comment "do not change this" in the template remains accurate.

issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2, Controller description) says "Each method takes a `Consumer<List<Note>>` parameter..." but the template and solution code for PersonController use `Consumer<List<Person>>`. This is a copy/paste naming error in the problem text that can confuse students about the expected type and mapping (Person vs Note) when implementing client-side controller methods for persons.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement text to reference Person (not Note). Change the sentence to: "Each method takes a Consumer<List<Person>> parameter, which has to be called after a response is received" so it matches the template and solution signatures and avoids confusion.
